Jan Oblak was impressing multiple teams in Europe whilst playing for Slovenian club Olimpija, and eventually earned a trial at Liverpool.

The Slovenian international flew from Slovenia to England to participate in his Liverpool trial. However, Oblak had an injury.

With the news that Oblak was injured and a doubt for his trial, Sporting Director of Oblak’s parent club Olimpija said:

Simon Seslar: “There is nothing serious with the injury. Before the match with Maribor, he had pain in the muscle. But this does not mean the end for him.”

Whilst Seslar and Oblak were aware of a slight injury before being sent to Liverpool, they didn’t think it would hold him back from his trial. To their surprise, Liverpool sent Jan Oblak straight back to Olimpija and ended their interest at that point.

突發：Sky Sports西班牙轉會專家Guillem Balague報道，皇馬願意讓C朗離隊！

C朗對皇馬沒有兌現續約的承諾感到失望，希望離隊完結在皇馬9年的生涯，皇馬亦願意讓C朗離開。

皇馬希望曼聯與PSG進行價格競爭，從而收到89M英鎊轉會費，但曼聯的取態是，當C朗被掛牌時，球會不能顯示沒有興趣，但如此巨額的轉會費不可能被合理化在33歲的C朗身上，故以此價格回購C朗可能性不大。

C朗現時合約於2021年到期，上季歐聯決賽後皇馬承諾續約，但至今仍沒有兌現。

Liverpool's hit-and-miss academy: As Jurgen Klopp prepares to blood youth at Plymouth, how many of the club's 21st-century starlets made the grade?
By Sam Morshead For Mailonline
12:28 18 Jan 2017, updated 14:07 18 Jan 2017

Richie Partridge (Debut: 29/11/2000; 3 games, 0 goals)

The speedy winger (and Michael Owen's brother-in-law) saw his Liverpool career defined by two cruciate ligament injuries - one in 1999 and another in 2003. He left for Sheffield Wednesday in 2005 and now runs a physiotherapy clinic.

Jon Otsemobor (Debut: 06/11/2002; 6 games, 0 goals)

Made headlines after being shot in the buttocks and having his car set on fire within the space of two weeks but, aside from that, was a reliable defender who enjoyed spells with nine League clubs.

Neil Mellor (Debut: 04/12/2002; 22 games, 6 goals)

Perhaps best remembered at Anfield for a stunning goal against Arsenal in front of the Kop and helping Liverpool to a dramatic Champions League win over Olympiakos, Mellor is now plying his trade in the media.

Stephen Warnock (Debut: 10/08/2004; 67 games, 1 goal)

Overcoming three broken legs to make the grade at Liverpool, Warnock went on to become an established first-team player at Anfield and went to the 2010 World Cup with England. Left for Blackburn in 2007 and now at Wigan.

Darren Potter (Debut: 10/08/2004; 17 games, 0 goals)

The midfielder made most of his appearances for the Reds in the League Cup and Champions League before leaving for Sheffield Wednesday. Now at MK Dons.

Zak Whitbread (Debut: 26/10/2004; 7 goals, 0 games)

The American defender captained the Under 19 squad and was compared to Sami Hyypia but ultimately found himself loaned and then sold to Millwall. Last played for Shrewsbury in a 3-0 defeat at Swindon in May.

David Raven (Debut: 01/12/2004; 4 games, 0 goals)

An England youth international who captained his country at a number of age-group levels, Raven would go on to be a fans' favourite at Carlisle.

James Smith (Debut: 25/10/2006; 1 game, 0 goals)

A one-game wonder, the right back's sole appearance for the Liverpool first team came against Reading in the League Cup in 2006. He's since been on the books of Stockport, Southport and Vauxhall Motor, among others.

Lee Peltier (Debut: 25/10/2006; 4 games, 0 goals)

Hardly got a look-in at Liverpool after making his debut in a Champions League tie, but has since had a solid career at the likes of Huddersfield, Leicester and Leeds.

Damien Plessis (Debut: 05/04/2008; 8 games, 1 goal)

French holding midfielder Plessis pitched up from Lyon in 2007 and spent three years at the club without making an impact beyond an impressive debut showing against Arsenal. Spent 2016 with Maritimo in Portugal.

Stephen Darby (Debut: 12/11/2008; 6 games, 0 goals)

A full back, Darby captained Liverpool's FA Youth Cup-winning side of 2006 and reached Wembley with Swindon Town in the League One play-offs of 2010. Club captain at Bradford.

Miki Roque (Debut: 05/12/2006; 1 game, 0 goals)

Roque's Liverpool career constituted of a handful of minutes against Galatasaray in Istanbul. He sadly passed away in 2012 following a battle with pelvic cancer.

Jay Spearing (Debut: 09/12/2008); 55 games, 0 goals)

A combative former captain of the club's Under 18s, Spearing's first two games for Liverpool came against PSV Eindhoven and Real Madrid. He's currently fighting for League One promotion with Bolton.

Martin Kelly (Debut: 09/12/2008; 62 games, 1 goal)

The versatile defender showed plenty of promise while dealing with infuriating injuries and made the Euro 2012 England squad. Left for Crystal Palace in 2014.

Daniel Ayala (Debut: 16/08/2009; 5 games, 0 goals)

Signed for £160,000 from Sevilla, the centre back promised much during pre-season tours of Switzerland and Thailand in 2009 but never quite came good in any competition proper. Now at Middlesbrough.

Nathan Eccleston (Debut: 28/10/2009; 9 games, 0 goals)

The England youth international was sent out on loan seven times during his time with the Reds. Most recently with Bekescsaba in Hungary.

Dani Pacheco (Debut: 09/12/2009; 17 games, 0 goals)

Nicknamed 'The Assassin' during his time at Barcelona, the Spanish attacker joined the Reds in 2007, making his debut in a Champions League clash against Fiorentina two years later.

Jack Robinson (Debut: 09/05/2010; 11 games, 0 goals)

Aged 16 years and 250 days, Robinson became the youngest player to feature for Liverpool's first team when he came on as a substitute at Hull in 2010. Now at QPR.

Lauri Dalla Valle (Debut: 29/07/2010; 1 game, 0 goals)

Arrived in 2005 after time in the Inter Milan academy and went on to make his first-team debut at FK Rabotnicki in 2010. That was it, however, and the Finn moved to Fulham a month later.

David Amoo (Debut: 29/07/2010; 1 game, 0 goals)

The striker's only appearance came in a Europa League qualifier at FK Rabotnicki. Amoo, who finished fourth in the 100m at the English Schools games in 2005, has been with Partick since 2015.

Tom Ince (Debut: 22/09/2010; 1 game, 0 goals)

His Liverpool career consisting of a 106th-minute substitute appearance in a home defeat by League Two Northampton in the League Cup, Ince has made a name for himself elsewhere thanks to his efforts at Blackpool, Hull and Derby.

Jon Flanagan (Debut: 11/04/2011; 50 games, 1 goal)

Tipped for big things from a young age at Liverpool, Flanagan's breakthrough came in 2013-14 when, under Brendan Rodgers, the Reds came so close to the Premier League title. Sent out to Burnley on loan in the summer.

Raheem Sterling (Debut: 24/03/2012; 129 games, 23 goals)

Picked up as a 15-year-old from QPR, the Jamaica-born winger became one of the most expensive players in the world when sold to Manchester City in 2015.

Adam Morgan (Debut: 23/08/2012; 3 games, 0 goals)

The Liverpudlian was the Under 18s' top goalscorer during 2010-11 but never managed to transfer that form to the first-team squad. Left for Yeovil in 2014)

Andre Wisdom (Debut: 20/09/2012; 22 games, 1 goal)

Signed from Bradford aged 14, the defender won the Victory Shield with England Under 16s in 2008. Since graduating to the first team, Wisdom has been on loan at Derby, West Brom and Norwich, and is currently with Red Bull Salzburg.

Jerome Sinclair (Debut: 26/09/2012; 5 games, 1 goal)

The forward broke Robinson's record in 2012, coming off the bench against West Brom at the ripe old age of 16 years and six days. Signed for Watford last summer.

Conor Coady (Debut: 08/11/2012; 2 games, 0 goals)

An England Under 17 European Championship winner, Coady only made two appearances for the Reds. Has since played for Sheffield United, Huddersfield and Wolves.

Jordon Ibe (Debut: 19/05/2013; 58 games, 4 goals)

A slightly different scenario, in that Ibe had already made his professional bow by the time he arrived at Liverpool, the skilful winger was bought from Wycombe as a 16-year-old. Sold to Bournemouth in the last transfer window.

Brad Smith (Debut: 29/12/2013; 11 games, 1 goal)

A lightning quick wing back, Aussie international Smith debuted at Chelsea in 2013 and spent time on loan at Swindon before moving to Bournemouth last summer.

Jordan Rossiter (Debut: 23/09/2014; 5 games, 1 goal)

For a kid who represented the club in the NextGen Under 19 competition aged 15, Rossiter never quite hit the heights expected of him. Moved to Glasgow in the summer.

Cameron Brannagan (Debut: 17/09/2015; 9 games, 0 goals)

Spotted playing youth football in Salford, Brannagan signed for the Reds aged nine. He made his Premier League bow against Swansea last term.

Pedro Chirivella (Debut: 17/09/2015; 5 games, 0 goals)

The Spaniard arrived from Valencia aged 16 in 2013 but didn't get a Premier League start for three years. When he did, at Swansea, he was substituted at half-time. Currently on loan with Go Ahead Eagles.

Connor Randall (Debut: 28/10/2015; 7 games, 0 goals)

Right back Randall made his professional bow on loan at Shrewsbury and has since had a handful of games for the Reds' first team.

Sheyi Ojo (Debut: 08/01/2016; 12 games, 1 goal)

Liverpool paid MK Dons £2million for the then-England Under 16 international in 2011. Made his pro debut for Wigan while on loan at the DW Stadium but returned to make eight Premier League appearances last season.

Ovie Ejaria (Debut: 20/09/2016; 6 games, 0 goals)

Arriving on Merseyside from Arsenal, the Nigerian made his bow for the Reds against Derby in the EFL Cup this season.

Trent Alexander-Arnold (Debut: 25/10/2016; 5 games, 0 goals)

A full back under Jurgen Klopp, Alexander-Arnold spent much of his youth career as a central midfielder. The nephew of Manchester United club secretary John Alexander, he made his debut against Tottenham this term.

Ben Woodburn (Debut: 26/11/2016; 3 games, 1 goal)

Having been with Liverpool's academy since he was eight years old, the joy of scoring in front of the Kop on his debut against Leeds in November was almost overwhelming for the Chester-born teenager. Now the Red's youngest-ever goalscorer.
